neutron/agent/dhcp/agent.py.message: I think it's ok, just needs a brief comment why it's done.
The next FixedIntervalLoopingCall has default param "initial_delay=None", which means it will be run immediately, so why add this?

Yes, most of time, the _report_state will executed earlier than sync, but a few times it will be late(perhaps because of the performance of FixedIntervalLoopingCall), I test several times, the probability is less then 10%, but when it happened, all the created network before won't be synced to this node, unless restart dhcp-agent.

I add it here to make sure the _report_state is completed executed before putting it into FixedIntervalLoopingCall management.

ovsdbapp/backend/ovs_idl/connection.py.message: Did you mean to also pass *args here?

One of the reasons I didn't do this initially was that there were so many configuration options that could be passed and I could tell they were just adding more so I didn't want to keep updating to mirror the python-ovs API: register_column() and then cond_change() happened, etc.

Capturing everything that you might want to configure ends up being a lot of arguments (tables, table w/ columns, table w/ conditions, etc.), so I just decided to go with "each Idl can override this classmethod and do whatever they want and no super() calls". It just seemed like there wasn't a lot of benefit to converting lines of code into lines of arguments. Best I came up with to handle all (existing) cases would be to pass something like:

 restrictions=[
     SchemaTable('Logical_Switch'),
     SchemaTable('Port_Group', columns=['name', 'acls']),
     SchemaTable('Chassis', conditions=[['uuid', '==', '$uuid']],
 ]

which just looks a lot like calling register_table()/register_column()/cond_change() which is kind of why the SchemaHelper exists, to translate those calls into the underlying structures on the TableSchema.

Anyway, that's enough of a history lesson. If it simplifies things, I can also see the argument for at least handling helper/tables which are fairly simple args here and leaving the more complex columns/conditions args for outside ovsdbapp subclasses.

On the *args thing, I wouldn't worry about subclasses changing the signature. There's no case where we'd ever call from_server(), a classmethod, and not know which one we were getting. Not that it hurts leaving *args in, it's just a nit/personal preference thing though. Doesn't really bother me leaving it in.

idl.Idl [1] accepts only two positional args, "remote" and "schema_helper". If that changes, we'll need to change this call.

[1]https://github.com/openvswitch/ovs/blob/721488d4a5f497f5693e286cf6f1916804bce2eb/python/ovs/db/idl.py#L105-L106

OK, now I remember why I did it: to make the method signature flexible enough for some particular implementations. For example: https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/src/branch/master/neutron/plugins/ml2/drivers/ovn/mech_driver/ovsdb/ovsdb_monitor.py#L638

--> this from_server implementation is passing 3 positional arguments instead of 2. With this proposal, this specific method won't override the signature.
note: the above restrictions example actually leaves out support for the 'readonly' argument for register_columns(). So yeah, that's why I just left all register_* up to non-ovsdbapp stuff.
The perhaps let's not implement *args in from_server()? This way we could pass anything to from_server but it will never be used anywhere.

playbooks/roles/matrix-gerritbot/files/g.message: #admin and #zuul don't exist -- should we drop them from this patch for now?

I agree that would be best -- however with no existing framework for doing that, I didn't think it was appropriate to push that burden onto this effort.

At the very least, I don't think we shoud be putting new files that control the opendev system into openstack/project-config.

I'm surprised that consensus seems to be to keep this semi-changing, user-focused config file here.  This is not something that needs system-config-core oversight of once in operation.

I buy that openstack/project-config is probably not the home for it.  However, https://opendev.org/opendev/project-config/ could work just as well IMO and provides somewhere for people who are more project-focused than devop-focused to help manage it.  

I feel like this split of responsibilities is a real feature of our CD story and worth keeping.
In IRC Tristan mentioned the bot would exit if it can't join the rooms, so I think we should reduce this to only #test.
That sounds like a good idea, is there a sync-opendev-project-config role we can use?

playbooks/roles/matrix-gerritbot/tasks/m.message: I think that we should discuss continuing to keep this in project-config.  This feels like something projects should control and not necessarily need infra-root review.  My personal preference is to keep it separate.  Even if not, this should likely come from group vars (see note below on templating the dhall).

Yeah, but project-config is in the openstack org.  It's actually better to move this into system-config so it's not controlled by the openstack project any more.  Doing that *helps* us move towards our goal of moving opendev out of openstack.

I bet if I scroll back at some point someone said use YAML as that's what we've got everywhere.  
So it's probably one of these cases where you ask 3 people and get 4 opinions.

It just seems to me that if there's ever anything wrong, then I don't just have to understand the dhall that comes out the other end, but also the YAML YATP (yet another transformation process).  When we have more channels, almost certainly we'll have lists of channels in a config yaml that are read by ansible and then put into this intermediate .yaml config via jinja templating.  So in this case our yaml template turns into a yaml file that is a yaml template for conversion to a dhall configuration file ...

I think I'd rather just see a config.dhall.j2 that generates something sane from an Ansible variable (which is YAML anyway).

If we split the config into project-config then I think we could do an include_vars: to read the YAML config file into a variable, then use that variable to template out the .j2

I feel *very* strongly that what we should ask end users (and remember, the people who will be adding channels to this are the opendev end users, not us) to edit yaml files.

I don't care how many times it gets transformed in the process.  What the end user has to copy/pase/edit to configure a channel is all that matters.

I think if you want to replace yaml with dhall across the board, it should be proposed in an infra-spec.

(I don't want to mislead you -- I'm not in favor of it, and I don't think it's worth your time to do.  But if you feel strongly about it and would be willing to do the work, that's the process to try to get consensus on it.)

> I think clark was not opposed to using dhall directly, and I'd rather propose that in the next PS since that would safely solve the templating and importing.

I was trying to express a few things in IRC and maybe that got mixed up.

* Not changing the config language is important for our existing users (eg keep yaml config).
* Repetition in the config language seems like a bug in the software not the serialization format. There are ways around the repetition if people don't like that. Have the application understand defaults directly rather than doing that in a configuration language. Or Encode defaults in a separate section of yaml (that users can ignore).
* I don't know that repetition is a major issue for us because many of our channels use very specific configs for the events and branches they care about.
* I did concede that if the yaml conversion wasn't possible for some reason we could probably live with dhall. But from what I've heard yaml is possible it may just not be as nice to some people. I think that we should stick to yaml to keep a consistent config in that case.

I do not understand why any templating is involved? the old config does not do any templating. Can we not keep the old yaml config and simply supply a static list of "here are the things to care about" to the process?

Note that the configuration is not modified by the transformation, the yaml-to-dhall just changes its representation, and the result is isomorphic (e.g. you can convert it back). So I think it is fine to use YAML here.

I would prefer to keep this separation of concern where the validation and templating is managed before the runtime using dhall, but if you prefer to use jinja, then we should make the bot do the transformation transparently (similarly to using yaml.load in a dynamic language). Like that there is no need to combine jinja and dhall.

I agree with this.

Keeping yaml is about keeping our user experience consistent and simple. Asking opendev users to learn and use dhall just for this one config is a bridge too far.

Additionally, as clarkb said, the repetition in the current config is minimal, and actually makes things very clear. Most people care about the config for their specific channel. It doesn't matter what other channels are doing to them. Everything is self contained in a single location. We don't need templating or functional config - in fact, I'd say those would be negative features *for our specific users and use case*.

The gerrit service is using git config, perhaps we could add gerritbot setting in there?

I find it cleaner to manage repetition, import and templating at the configuration layer so that we can keep the runtime simple, instead of implementing a hierarchy or template system in each program.
I would prefer we do not use yaml because of its many flaws and incompatible implementations. I feel strongly that we should build on a better system and consider YAML as legacy.

Thank you for the helpful suggestion, though I don't think Dhall (at least in its current form) is the right choice for an infra-spec. The lack of type inference makes it hard to use for dynamic configuration such as the one used by Ansible.

I find YAML and Jinja inefficient and it might be worth investigating alternatives as long term solution, e.g. I would keep an eye on https://2021.splashcon.org/home/conflang-2021

I'd like to just see templates/config.dhall.j2 and then populate that from a Ansible variable loaded like

 - name: Sync project-config
   include_role:
     name: sync-project-config

    include_vars: /opt/project-config/matrix-gerritbot/config.yaml

 - name: Write config
   template:
     src: gerritbot.dhall.j2
     dest: /var/lib/matrix-gerritbot/config/gerritbot.dhall

tacker/vnfm/plugin.py.message: why call it twice at line 707 and line 674?
The trigger for mgmt_call is different. Scale in calls mgmt_call before the resource is deleted. Scale out calls mgmt_call after the resource is created.
IMO, you can add handle both scale_in and scale_out here. You should create other function for flexible handling.
I think we should call this in case of scale-in too.

I see that you process scale action IN and OUT in different places. For example, you process scale_out inside _vnf_policy_action_wait function but scale_in is outside.  

Because I see '_handle_vnf_scale_mgmt' function can process for both cases, so I think you should use 'ACTION_SCALE_IN_OUT' to process 2 cases and put the code on the right position.

IMO, I think mgmt has difference of process and timing between scale action IN and OUT.

SCALE_IN's mgmt has process to close VDU. It want to be called before execute the SCALE_IN action.
SCALE_OUTs mgmt has process to start VDU. It want to be called after  execute the SCALE_OUT action.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: I don't think adding blacklist paths is not sufficient. Even after this change, you cannot prevent from leaking file contents located outside of the specified paths on a web server.

I agree with Akihiro here and this change still leave risks that users can access files to /var or /usr .

IMO we should completely disable the current behavior to use contents as path or url. Even usage of url is still risky because it allows users to try attacking any internal servers reachable from the node where horizon runs.

I have submitted a series of changes so that mistral use definiton passed as only raw, which I believe is the safe approach here.

https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/python-mistralclient/+/800950
https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/mistral-dashboard/+/800952

After reading this description, it seems that mistral-dashboard should prevent the usage of this feature. When misralclient is used locally (this is the primary usecase of CLI), the utility loads the file content with a local user privilege.
However, in case of UI implementation, the utility is run on a web server. I think this is the root cause of the security issue.

rally/rally-plugins/dynamic-workloads/ba.message:
don't cache fips. Instead get the fip from the server in line 126.
Reason for this is -
_list_servers in line 108, can return the servers created by this tenant in previous iterations. So in that case, self.fips might not be having these servers fips.

I just found another possible problem though. The trunk network simulation workload also creates servers with fips. So this will cause conflict when server migration and trunk network simulation workload are executed together. I think the only way to get a proper solution to this problem is to have a method to isolate objects created by different workloads. But I am not sure how to do it.
Ack. I will try and make changes to the code accordingly now.
Got it, thanks for the clarification. You can ignore my comment then.
don't isolate them. Instead after retrieving the items check if the items have what you want
that will be great i.e retrieving servers with fip

I think your comment is required though, as right now the code only migrates servers with floating IPs that were created in the current iteration. I think, instead of caching fips, I can just check if the server has a floating IP in lambda function in line 108.

The reason why I used this fips cache is because _list_servers was returning servers created by the create_delete_servers function also, and those don't have fips, so it was giving errors. There should be a way to differentiate between servers created by create_delete_servers and servers created by server_boot_floatingip. 
I think I can cache the servers that were created by create_delete_servers instead of caching fips, and check in the lambda function on line 108 if the server is not present in the create_delete_servers cache.
Another alternative is to make create_delete_servers also create servers with floating IPs instead of without floating IPs, so we won't have to worry about this issue at all.

ADD THE STEP HERE TOO:

   #. **For OpenStack only:** Due to the additional openstack services’
      containers running on the controller host, the size of the docker
      filesystem needs to be increased from the default size of 30G to 60G.

      .. code-block:: bash

         # check existing size of docker fs
         system host-fs-list controller-0
         # check available space (Avail Size (GiB)) in cgts-vg LVG where docker fs is located
         system host-lvg-list controller-0
         # if existing docker fs size + cgts-vg available space is less than
         # 80G, you will need to add a new disk partition to cgts-vg.
         # There must be at least 20GB of available space after the docker
         # filesystem is increased.

            # Assuming you have unused space on ROOT DISK, add partition to ROOT DISK.
            # ( if not use another unused disk )

            # Get device path of ROOT DISK
            system host-show controller-0 --nowrap | fgrep rootfs

            # Get UUID of ROOT DISK by listing disks
            system host-disk-list controller-0

            # Create new PARTITION on ROOT DISK, and take note of new partition’s ‘uuid’ in response
            # Use a partition size such that you’ll be able to increase docker fs size from 30G to 60G
            PARTITION_SIZE=30
            system system host-disk-partition-add -t lvm_phys_vol controller-0 <root-disk-uuid> ${PARTITION_SIZE}

            # Add new partition to ‘cgts-vg’ local volume group
            system host-pv-add controller-0 cgts-vg <NEW_PARTITION_UUID>
            sleep 2    # wait for partition to be added

            # Increase docker filesystem to 60G
            system host-fs-modify controller-0 docker=60

Because according to SOL003, type VnfInfoModifications, 
there is the following description for its attribute,
take vnf_instance_name as an example:
"If present, this attribute signals modifications of the
"vnfInstanceName" attribute in "VnfInstance" as defined
in clause 5.5.2.12."
Therefore, if a attribute is not modified in the request, 
we should not assign a value to it, even if the value been assigned is None.

However, "getattr" is indeed better than "__getattribute__", so I have changed "__getattribute__" to "getattr".

“TypeError: Object of type VimConnectionInfo is not JSON serializable”.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: Concept makes sense (this recently came up on the ML) but we should have a test that verifies this change does what's intended.

Note to reviewers: this patch will resolve the issue described on the ML [1] where due to bug #1780799 users could encounter a result from the 'placement-status upgrade check' where the number of incomplete consumers found can be negative.

This is obviously confusing for users and in order to make the status check happy, they have to manually clean up old rows that were left behind by bug #1780799. While such a cleanup is something nice/good to do anyway, having the orphaned rows does not pose any harm to the upgrade or operation of the system (generally speaking -- if you have sufficiently too many orphaned rows, you could see DB performance degradation). 

Because the orphaned rows are not actively harmful for the upgrade or deployment, I think it would be better that they not be flagged as such.

This patch removes orphans from consideration when checking for incomplete consumers, so that the status check will only find legit incomplete consumers that could cause problems for the upgraded deployment.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2020-October/018253.html

I'd like to understand/confirm how the implementation avoids the a bug similar to https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1423648

Basically, if you create 2 shares at the same time, looks like the policy could be violated due to a race condition. Both validations would happen in parallel, but according to [0], it will not proper validate the restriction.

Hi, I don't see the same issue - because we are not having groups.

So if I say my new shares B1 and B2 should not be on the same host like share A and I fire two calls for B1 and B2 at the same time, it is okay. I guess you are saying case (b) above will be Fail, but one could argue that for affinity the match is an OR (I want it close to any one of the shares I mention) and that for antiaffinity it should be AND (these are the shares to stay away from, no matter what back end they are on).
Or maybe both should be ANDs.

In any case please make the semantics a little more specific.

We had a quick internal discussion on that point. It seems like a hard AND would be a better option, because the user expectation is most likely that a new share gets affinity to both (or multiple) other shares. If that is a soft OR affinity - user won't have a clear way of finding out which share was picked for the affinity. But, even if we provide a way (an extra endpoint, etc.) - it would require an extra step or an API call to figure out how the share was scheduled which seems rather unintuitive.

So, in our opinion - that has to be hard AND for both affinity/anti-affinity. And in case the conditions cannot be met - just fail the share creation.

From what i understand, we had a discussion at the PTG to consider share groups as an alternative, however, we discarded the idea based on a few limitations. However, it'd be nice to note that down here:


Affinity is also possible with share groups. However, there are some limitations of share groups to the use case proposed:

1) Affinity/Anti-affinity is only required at the time of provisioning the resource, and not at any other point during its lifetime. Shares created within share groups today are tied to the share group throughout their lifetime.
2) Current feature limitations with share groups include the inability to migrate or replicate shares within a share group
3) While achieving affinity is possible with share groups, anti-affinity is not.
Done

Yes, I did catch that discussion, and thanks for mentioning this in the spec; but i didn't see answers for the problems presented:

- Will the feature involve deletion of hints as shares referenced get deleted?
- The migration impact isn't called out in this specification; I'd like to understand that a bit more; 
  When migrating a share that has hints, we'd need to qualify/disqualify a host chosen by the
  administrator based on the hints provided by the user; doing this would be great and expected - however, would it be possible to ignore these hints and force a migration?

Yeah, my problem with (1) is that the "scheduler_hints" field isn't exactly a key value pair that we can feed into a decent index, so yes - it could be an expensive database operation to gather all the shares that hint towards a share being deleted. Rather than doing that, we could possibly store this as share metadata where:

1) you have the advantage of a more structured storage, providing faster lookups
2) we can disallow deletion of these metadata items via RBAC policy and default the policy to project administrators
3) no change is necessary in the JSON response schema for the share APIs
4) no change is necessary in the share migration API - administrators can delete any offending scheduler hint metadata and perform the migration

We have discussed [*] the possibility of introducing three kinds of metadata:

1) Service related metadata - like manila tagging an export location as preferred, or admin_only
2) Admin controlled metadata - For stuff like we're talking about above - where regular users shouldn't be able to manipulate some reserved metadata keys (we'd enforce this via RBAC policies)
3) User metadata - regular metadata

We're actively working on getting the metadata work [*] completed in the Xena cycle - however, we can cut out the portion to enable policy controlled metadata and get that completed as a shared priority for both specs if you wish.

[*] https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/manila-specs/specs/wallaby/metadata-for-share-resources.html

1. As for deletion of hints when a share is deleted -> I'm not sure to be honest. This has to scale for potentially very large hints table. Yet, share deletion operation is async, so maybe not a big deal?
2. Added a paragraph about migration.

1) Yes, agree. Yet I don't think we can simply discard this information after scheduling because it makes hard for user/admin to find where the shares are actually located. See previous conversation with Tom about it.
2) Exactly, we wanted to keep them to be able to respect the 'scheduler_hints' when a share is migrated between the hosts.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
so the analasy in the bz was wrong

post-copy is supported with hugepageas and cpu pinning

what was missing is you need to set 

 ovs-vsctl set Open_vSwitch . other_config:vhost-postcopy-support=true

in the ovs db to enable postcopy supprot in the vhost-user backend


this is the qemu instance log form the failing vm migration 
http://rhos-ci-logs.lab.eng.tlv2.redhat.com/logs/rcj/DFG-nfv-16.2-director-3cont-2comp-ipv4-geneve-ovn-hci-dpdk-sriov-ctlplane-dataplane-bonding-hybrid/7/computehciovndpdksriov-1/var/log/libvirt/qemu/instance-00000032.log.gz
where we see "vhost-user backend not capable of postcopy"

specificly the backend not qemu or libvirt is not capbale of postcopy because it does nto reqport
the VHOST_USER_PROTOCOL_F_PAGEFAULT feature flag unless you enable postcopy
which qemu checks for https://gitlab.com/qemu-project/qemu/-/blob/master/hw/virtio/vhost-user.c#L1836

so we can disabel post-copy temporaly for ovs-dpdk only

or we fix vhost-user support by setting 

 ovs-vsctl set Open_vSwitch . other_config:vhost-postcopy-support=true

when post copy is enabled which is the longer but likely more correct lonterm fix.

I can't reproduce the bug, the floating IP works very well in my environment, and I don't think there's anything wrong with you captured packets. But, The east/west traffic will produce duplicate reply packets occasionally, this is caused by some residual tap devices [1] (Restart network node(with dhcp-agent or l3-agent) can produce these residual tap devices). These residual tap devices will result in some residual flows:
  "table=2, priority=4,dl_vlan=287,dl_dst=fa:16:3e:f8:8e:51 actions=mod_dl_src:fa:16:3e:71:9d:7b,load:0x5->NXM_OF_IN_PORT[],strip_vlan,resubmit(,60)"
The flow will permit invalid packets(with dst mac fa:16:3e:f8:8e:51) through, these packets will be output to br-tun or br-vlan again, so the replicate reply packets produced.

Please confirm whether the sg-* port remains at other nodes and you can pull my last patch set to test.

neutron/plugins/ml2/drivers/openvswitch/.message:
IMO, this is a security problem. You'll have a non VLAN tagged packet inside the bridge, sent to a table and not to a port. With this action you are deisolating this traffic.

Only NORMAL action (which strips the VLAN if needed) or forced output to ports (along with manual VLAN strip action) should remove the VLAN isolation inside the int-br.

No, I don't think I am de-isolating this traffic. The isolation of traffic is implemented by 'reg6' in subsequent flow tables. And, the local qr-* port is an access port(the packet that includes an 802.1Q header it will be treated as invalid), so that we must strip the VLAN tag in order to fully simulate local qr-* port.

Why they must in same L2 netwrok?

I'm sorry to reply so late. It is because we want to let router proxy response the mac address of vip. And we also want to achieve LVS-DR later, which requires the amphora/server/qrouter in the same L2 network.

> I don't think requiring the pool members behind the amphora
 > instance to be on the same L2 is a good idea. It really limits the
 > usefulness and degrades performance by creating one-armed load
 > balancers.
 > I would also note that direct-return (DR) has a number of issues
 > that limit it's usefulness if you cannot modify the pool members,
 > something Octavia does not do or support today.
 > I think we can set it up so the Amphora do DR and bypass going back
 > through a neutron network node in this scenario, but I think DR for
 > the pool members may not be feasible or something we should attempt
 > at the same time.

In my company's version, LVS-DR mode support is required due to the high performance requirements. For this reason the same l2 network needs to be supported. I discussed this with a colleague and as you said, the same L2 network can cause some issues with centralization. If we leave aside the limitations of LVS-DR, yes, I think that this solution is perfectly suited to follow the current octavia Design of vip-net. We can look further into the DR mode in a later version.

I don't think requiring the pool members behind the amphora instance to be on the same L2 is a good idea. It really limits the usefulness and degrades performance by creating one-armed load balancers.
I would also note that direct-return (DR) has a number of issues that limit it's usefulness if you cannot modify the pool members, something Octavia does not do or support today.
I think we can set it up so the Amphora do DR and bypass going back through a neutron network node in this scenario, but I think DR for the pool members may not be feasible or something we should attempt at the same time.

I guess you want to make neutron router as distributor. If so, It's a gool idea. But I don't think the neutron need to extend , the current neutron can completely realize this scheme. The neutron API support add routes which have same destination and different gateways to a router. Like this: 
"openstack router set 79cf5d9d-c4ab-45d7-8959-30963cba2ea4 --route destination=10.30.30.35/32,gateway=10.30.30.2 --route destination=10.30.30.35/32,gateway=10.30.30.3"
The "10.30.30.35" can be as the VIP of amphorae. So by this way, the neutron router can be any mode. And I don't think the ARP proxy need to enable. 

But, maybe that is neutron's bug: the qrouter-* namespace's route entity as below:
10.30.30.35 via 10.30.30.3 dev qr-905cfb1e-43 
10.30.30.35 via 10.30.30.2 dev qr-905cfb1e-43
I think we just need to fixed it, make the route entity like this:
10.30.30.35 
	nexthop via 10.30.30.2 dev qr-905cfb1e-43 weight 1 
	nexthop via 10.30.30.3 dev qr-905cfb1e-43 weight 1

Wouldn't the VIP on the qrouter be owned by the Octavia service account? We don't want users able to manipulate it's settings really.
Also, I have concerns about the ARP proxy statements, especially with the various DVR implementations in neutron. Many of them have crippled ARP support.
Can you explain more the need for the ARP proxy?

> Wouldn't the VIP on the qrouter be owned by the Octavia service
 > account? We don't want users able to manipulate it's settings
 > really.
 > Also, I have concerns about the ARP proxy statements, especially
 > with the various DVR implementations in neutron. Many of them have
 > crippled ARP support.
 > Can you explain more the need for the ARP proxy?

Yes, I also think VIP should belong to the octavia service account. I'd like to further clarify the issue of ARP proxies.  User access VIP, and we enable ARP proxy on qrouter in order to "direct" the traffic to qrouter. The qrouter proxies its own mac address and accepts traffic from the user, then sends the data to amphora through ECMP. The back end of amphora is also configured with VIP, but the response to ARP is turned off. This allows amphora to passively receive traffic, but not actively "steal" it. This ensures that the traffic is distributed along the correct path.

Sorry I don't know whether it is my fault, because when I config my qrouter like you said, the second route entity override the first one. On the other hand, I don't know whether the bug you refered is a real bug...maybe it is just designed for this way?

This can be done today in neutron, but it is a blind round roubin ECMP, which is not good for maintaining session persistence between the client and the amphora.
This limits the number of amphora that can be in a cluster and can seriously degrade TLS performance.
Neutron will have to be modified to support a consistent hash (OVS supports this today).

Can we list why in this document?
I think it is due to the consistent hash, but I would like to capture any other reasons here.

> Can we list why in this document?
 > I think it is due to the consistent hash, but I would like to
 > capture any other reasons here.

This is mainly to configure ECMP on the qrouter. By configuring different nexthop, linux itself is able to achieve stream affinity with 5 tuple hash. However, it is true that there are some problems with 5 tuple hash, which I will discuss in detail later.

Agreed, the amphora cluster manager and/or HM would handle this.
We should consider the case of "draining" as well, which is how do you gracefully remove an amphora from the ECMP cluster to contract the number of amphora. In some load balancers setting the weight to 0 means "don't send new conections, but allow current", can we do this with the neutron implmentation?
It would be nice to capture the "drain" use case in this document as well.

This is because we can no longer use vrrp to guarantee availability in active-active mode.Vrrp can only be used in active-standby mode. For amphora clusters, we need to find new ways to probe the availability of each amphorad. For example, using the following icmp probes.
Again, I'm not sure it should be limited.

> Again, I'm not sure it should be limited.

Yes, of course. We no longer force everything to be under the same l2 network, so vip can come from the same vip-net and belong to the octavia service account.

There are a lot of complications with this. To do DR with the pool members it requires changes inside the pool member, which Octavia does not have access to.
I think we should not attempt to target DR in this initial specification.

> There are a lot of complications with this. To do DR with the pool
 > members it requires changes inside the pool member, which Octavia
 > does not have access to.
 > I think we should not attempt to target DR in this initial
 > specification.

Yes, the DR mode is quite complicate. In our existing implementation, we use openflow to modify the source IP of the traffic arriving at the member to achieve DR mode. But it does have problems. So maybe we can talk about it in the future, and ignore DR mode for now.

It would be nice if we can continue to not require a floating IP for the "external" network access. Can't we still plug directly into the external network?
The NAT of a flip is a performance drain and causes problems for IPv6 VIPs.

> It would be nice if we can continue to not require a floating IP
 > for the "external" network access. Can't we still plug directly
 > into the external network?
 > The NAT of a flip is a performance drain and causes problems for
 > IPv6 VIPs.

For the average north-south traffic, this performance loss isn't that unacceptable. If we want to plug directly into an external network, we need the ability to operate and configure the ECMP for the external network, but I'm not sure how this should be implemented. However it's true that the impact to octavia code is not significant.
In a production environment, the external network usually connect to a physical switch, that is out of neutron's control. So, I'm afraid that the floating IP is necessary.

We should target a consistent hash instead of a simple 5 tuple. 5 tuple means that if we add or remove amphora all connections get redistributed. We want a follow on to Active/Active to be dynamic load balancing where the amphora will scale up and down. It also improves maintenance capabilities.

Good news, our network team is planning to use HMARK in iptables instead of ip routes with several nexthops. You can see that part in our Neutron spec, if that comes true, existing flows will not be redistributed when Octavia find an amphora unreachable and remove it temporarily.

Yes it's a pretty tricky one....But the good news is that higher versions of the linux kernel seem to have implemented consistent hash.http://archive.linuxvirtualserver.org/html/lvs-devel/2018-03/msg00023.html
We can discuss together how to take advantage of this.
Again, I think there are lot of issues with DR that need to be addressed.
Is this true in all ML/2 drivers? Again here I think consistent hashing may be required to make sure sessions are persisted.

Yes, the DVR mode require qrouter is distributed. Maybe different ML2 drivers will not make a difference?

This is all already handled by the amphora agent, VRRP, and health manager. We may need to make some changes to make down detection faster in this use case, but I don't think we need to do this ICMP setup.
For example, we may be able to do an in-band test with the ACM.

> This is all already handled by the amphora agent, VRRP, and health
 > manager. We may need to make some changes to make down detection
 > faster in this use case, but I don't think we need to do this ICMP
 > setup.
 > For example, we may be able to do an in-band test with the ACM.

Yes, octavia implements an excellent set of mechanisms for health checks.But as I said before, vrrp has lost its usefulness in detecting cluster availability. We want to inherit octavia's original health management mechanism, but need another way to replace vrrp. This may also require the health manager with stronger management capabilities for amphora.

But your words enlightened me. I was looking for information about vrrp support for cluster availability and came across a new protocol called "vrrpe". This protocol enables multiple routers to work simultaneously and ensure high availability. It was proposed by H3C and implemented on their own routers. If we can implement the vrrpe protocol on amphora, then we can do it with minimal cost. active-active topology. we don't have to use a separate distributor and we don't have to think about the ECMP issues. See this document for more details:

https://techhub.hpe.com/eginfolib/ networking/docs/switches/5920-5900/5998- 5303a_hi-avail_cg/content/414623810.htm

But for now, it's just an idea....

server_addrs is an array of addresses. I keep the same name that it is used for persistence because I did not want to add more complexity.
I found that SERVICE_PARAM_SECTION_KUBERNETES_CERTIFICATES is also an array and it is in plural form. Is there any format issue with this?

I am checking the format errors and I will push a new patch .

It was implemented in that way. I think that it was thought to reduce complexity. Having 2 arrays will require checking both sizes or having a rule for those edge cases. Furthermore, I keep the default port value to simplify the usage: the user could set only the server_addrs parameter and default port will be used. I also think that setting a server_addrs without server_port (not even the default one) will produce an invalid collectd network configuration. However, this situation could be handled on collectd template.

To sum up, I did not modify parameters types nor names. I have implemented the interface in order to allow the user to configure them with service-parameter command.

If you consider that it is important to have the flexibility to configure several ports, I could try to implement that but I have concerns about edge cases.
What I'm trying to get at is why isn't the server_port also an array ?

This doesn't ensure that each entry in the list contains a port. If no port is present it looks like puppet would fail to unlock the host.

on upgrade migration from 21.05 to current release, will migration (e.g. at config/controllerconfig/controllerconfig/upgrade-scripts)   be required for the previously defined server_addrs?

No, it should not be necessary. Previously, server_addrs was set with a default value and the user could not modify it. Variable name was changed because it contains now IP:Port for each server. These modifications can be seen on stx-puppet.

sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/common/utils.message: I don't think letters or underscores or dashes are part of a valid IPv4 address.  Only numbers and periods and a colon for the port.
Arguably the last one shouldn't be accepted either, since only integers from 1 to 65535 are valid port numbers.
Personally I'm in favour of making it as restrictive as possible to fail as early as possible.

ipaddress.ip_address() will validate IPv4/6 addresses (without ports)
ipaddress.IPv4Address() will validate just IPv4 addresses.
urlparse might work, but I think you'd have to ensure a netloc is returned

I don't think that neither. However, there were some cases where something invalid but really similar to an IPv4 was accepted. Furthermore, the behaviour was kind of erratic. Some invalid ranges were accepted but others were rejected.

Let me give you some examples to make it simpler.
Rejected: 292.168.0.1:12345
Accepted: 192.168.0.999999
Accepted: 192.168.0.999999:1234
Accepted: 192.168.0.999999:1234asd
With the old logic, if the 3 first field from IPv4 were valid, no matter what you put on the forth, it will be validated as a domain and it will be accepted.

Removing those special characters from this regex will lead into something like this:
Accepted (IPv4 validator): 192.168.0.123:1234
Rejected (IPv4 validator): 192.168.0.123:99999999
Accepted (domain validator): 192.168.0.123:1234asd

Anyways, this is a design decision. I just wanted to cover as much as possible, including edge cases. If only numbers should be checked to classify the string as IPv4, then I'll remove letters and special chars from regex.

krm-functions/cloud-init/certs/README.md.message: Was this file removed by mistake? It looks like these certs are still copied in the Dockerfile.

Cloud-init krm function depends on airshipctl go-package. Before my changes if you need to update something in krm-function it was necessary to make 2 commits: to airshipctl and after that to modify go.mod inside krm-function. That caused the issues: people forget to do the second step, e.g. it introduced issues with templater I'm resolving here in parallel. Another drawback was - if I kept that that - it would be necessary to make several commits to update kustomize. So I've reverted the process of how we're building krm-functions to the original version that was done by Dmitry Ukov and now certs are taken from the root of airshipctl. That's why it works, but we now can delete certs from here.. Also I think it's ok, because why should we have several copies of certs directories in different places of our repo :)

doc/source/admin/cpu-topologies.rst.message: I'd re-word this as "Besides the flavor extra spec,".

while we are updating the docs we should consider if we should remove referce to host numa nodes in the flavor docs when discribing the hw:numa_nodes option. 

the hw_numa* and hw:numa* image properties and flavor extra spec describe the virtual numa toplogy. it is not required that the virt driver map each virtual numa node to a different host numa node. that was an implemenation detail of the virt driver that is subject to change. although now that i type this i realise that the numa toplogy filter might be enforcing that which has implication for how we would have to model things in placement.

https://github.com/openstack/nova-specs/blob/master/specs/juno/implemented/virt-driver-numa-placement.rst#proposed-change

the detail of these are contained in the orginal spec.
they have not been change since they were added.
the semantics of what is required from an api point of view is less strict then the libvirt driver provides.

https://openstack.fortnebula.com:13808/v1/AUTH_e8fd161dc34c421a979a9e6421f823e9/zuul_opendev_logs_4df/683849/1/check/openstack-tox-docs/4df0a19/docs/admin/cpu-topologies.html
